site.name: rust.dev
site.positioning: A curated editorial publication and index for Rust in production: crypto (smart contracts + protocols), embedded, gaming, high-load systems, security, AI/data, events, and tooling.
site.disclaimer: Independent publication. Not affiliated with the Rust Project, Rust Foundation, or any protocol. No official logos or Rust mascots are used.

hero.headline: Rust × Crypto Intelligence
hero.subhead: A high-signal editorial desk + index for protocol engineering, Rust smart contracts, security, and the builders shipping it all.
bullets: Curated news briefs (no spam, no low-quality submissions)
Protocol + tooling index (Rust-first where it matters)
Conference calendar + talk playlists
Learning tracks for shipping production Rust in crypto

about_page.headline: Independent, community-driven, and aggressively high-signal.
about_page.body_md:
rust.dev is an independent, community-driven editorial index for Rust in production.

We focus on **signal over volume**: the tools, ecosystems, events, and creators that actually move Rust forward—from smart contracts and protocol engineering to embedded firmware, game development, high-load services, and AI/data.

Everything here is designed to be **linkable and indexable** (for search + AI): each entry includes primary sources, official docs, and a teaser video when it exists.

**Not affiliated** with the Rust Project or Rust Foundation. We don’t use official Rust logos/mascots.

sections.title: Editorial standard
bullets: Source-first: links to primary docs/releases whenever possible
No paid “reviews” disguised as editorial
No anonymous shilling
Security content is clearly labeled and linked to advisories

sections.title: What we cover
bullets: Rust smart contract frameworks (Anchor, CosmWasm, ink!, Soroban, Stylus)
Rust protocol + client engineering (Reth, Substrate, Solana stack, Lighthouse, libp2p)
Rust cryptography + ZK toolchains
Embedded Rust (no_std, Embassy, probe-rs, defmt, real hardware workflows)
Game dev in Rust (Bevy + rendering/tooling ecosystem)
High-load services + infra (Tokio, Tower, tracing, gRPC, performance engineering)
AI/data stacks in Rust (Candle/Burn, Polars, DataFusion, pipelines)
Major conferences and builder gatherings across all Rust verticals
Jobs and hiring sources (curated boards, no spam)

protocols.name: Solana
protocols.one_liner: High-throughput chain where on-chain programs are commonly written in Rust (often via Anchor).
rust_relevance: Rust is a primary language for Solana on-chain programs.
Anchor is a dominant framework simplifying program development.
protocols.about: Solana is one of the most Rust-native smart contract ecosystems: on-chain programs are commonly written in Rust, and the developer experience is heavily shaped by Anchor, SPL standards, and Rust serialization (often Borsh).
protocols.teaser: High-throughput chain where on-chain programs are commonly written in Rust (often via Anchor).

protocols.name: Polkadot / Substrate
protocols.one_liner: Rust-first blockchain SDK (Polkadot SDK) + Rust/WASM smart contracts with ink! on compatible chains.
rust_relevance: Substrate / Polkadot SDK is written in Rust and used to build runtimes and chains.
ink! enables Rust-to-WASM smart contracts.
protocols.about: Polkadot’s engineering stack is Rust-first: the Polkadot SDK (Substrate + related components) is written in Rust, runtimes compile to WASM, and ink! enables Rust smart contracts on compatible chains.
protocols.teaser: Rust-first blockchain SDK (Polkadot SDK) + Rust/WASM smart contracts with ink! on compatible chains.

protocols.name: NEAR
protocols.one_liner: Rust smart contracts via near-sdk-rs, with strong developer tooling for testing and workflows.
rust_relevance: near-sdk-rs is the core Rust toolkit for NEAR smart contracts.
Rust tooling exists for testing and automated workflows.
protocols.about: NEAR offers Rust smart contracts via near-sdk-rs and a mature testing workflow through near-workspaces-rs. It’s a practical environment for teams that want to ship Rust-to-WASM contracts with strong dev ergonomics.

youtube.title: NEAR Protocol (official channel) — Rust smart contracts & ecosystem updates

protocols.teaser: Rust smart contracts via near-sdk-rs, with strong developer tooling for testing and workflows.

protocols.name: Cosmos / CosmWasm
protocols.one_liner: Rust smart contracts compiled to WASM via CosmWasm, widely used across Cosmos appchains.
rust_relevance: CosmWasm is a Rust contract framework targeting WASM.
Strong shared libraries (cw-plus) and tooling exist for production contracts.
protocols.about: CosmWasm is the dominant Rust smart contract stack in the Cosmos ecosystem: contracts are written in Rust and compiled to WASM, with a large shared library ecosystem (cw-plus) and standardized tooling for production builds.

youtube.title: CosmWasm smart contracts in Rust (intro workshop)

protocols.teaser: Rust smart contracts compiled to WASM via CosmWasm, widely used across Cosmos appchains.

protocols.name: Bitcoin
protocols.one_liner: Rust ecosystem for wallets and Lightning integrations: rust-bitcoin, BDK, and LDK.
rust_relevance: rust-bitcoin provides core Bitcoin data structures and parsing.
BDK enables modern wallet development in Rust.
LDK enables Lightning integrations as a Rust SDK.
protocols.about: Bitcoin’s Rust ecosystem is strongest in wallet and payments infrastructure: rust-bitcoin provides core types and protocol parsing, BDK accelerates modern descriptor wallet development, and LDK enables Lightning integrations.
protocols.teaser: Rust ecosystem for wallets and Lightning integrations: rust-bitcoin, BDK, and LDK.

protocols.name: Ethereum (Rust stack)
protocols.one_liner: Rust execution clients and libraries: Reth for nodes; Alloy for app + RPC integrations.
rust_relevance: Reth is a Rust Ethereum execution layer implementation.
Alloy is a modern Rust library stack for interacting with EVM chains.
protocols.about: Ethereum’s Rust stack is increasingly credible: Reth is a modular Rust execution client, while Alloy provides a modern Rust toolkit for interacting with EVM chains (RPC, types, signing, etc.). For consensus, Lighthouse is a leading Rust client.
protocols.teaser: Rust execution clients and libraries: Reth for nodes; Alloy for app + RPC integrations.

protocols.name: Stellar / Soroban
protocols.one_liner: Rust smart contracts compiled to WASM using Soroban SDKs and tooling.
rust_relevance: Soroban contracts are written in Rust and compiled to WebAssembly.
The Soroban SDK and docs make Rust the default contract experience.
protocols.about: Soroban brings a Rust-first smart contract model to Stellar. If you want Rust-to-WASM contracts with a tight SDK and an ecosystem pushing developer experience, Soroban belongs on your radar.

youtube.title: Meridian 2025: It’s never been better to build on Stellar (Soroban era)

protocols.teaser: Rust smart contracts compiled to WASM using Soroban SDKs and tooling.

protocols.name: Arbitrum / Stylus
protocols.one_liner: Rust-to-WASM smart contracts on Arbitrum via Stylus, with an SDK and growing tooling ecosystem.
rust_relevance: Stylus enables Rust smart contracts by compiling to WASM for execution on Arbitrum.
Rust tooling includes an SDK, CLI, and developer guides.
protocols.about: Stylus is a major step toward Rust-native smart contracts in EVM ecosystems—without forcing teams into Solidity. Expect rapid iteration on tooling and best-practices as the ecosystem matures.

youtube.title: Stylus Pro Series (Rust smart contracts on Arbitrum)

protocols.teaser: Rust-to-WASM smart contracts on Arbitrum via Stylus, with an SDK and growing tooling ecosystem.

protocols.name: Aptos
protocols.one_liner: Layer-1 with a substantial Rust codebase (node + tooling), while smart contracts are authored in Move.
rust_relevance: Core components (node and supporting tooling) are written in Rust.
Rust SDKs and libraries are common for infrastructure and integrations.
protocols.about: Even in Move-based ecosystems, Rust remains a key language for node engineering, indexing, and infrastructure services. Aptos is a strong example of a modern Rust-heavy blockchain codebase.
protocols.teaser: Layer-1 with a substantial Rust codebase (node + tooling), while smart contracts are authored in Move.

protocols.name: Sui
protocols.one_liner: High-performance blockchain implemented primarily in Rust, with Move for on-chain logic.
rust_relevance: Core implementation is Rust-heavy (node, networking, runtime components).
Rust libraries exist for client and infrastructure development.
protocols.about: Sui is one of the most visible Rust-built L1s. Even if your contracts are written in Move, the surrounding infra story is deeply Rust-oriented.
protocols.teaser: High-performance blockchain implemented primarily in Rust, with Move for on-chain logic.

protocols.name: Fuel
protocols.one_liner: Modular execution layer and ecosystem with core components implemented in Rust (Fuel Core).
rust_relevance: Fuel Core (node) is implemented in Rust, making Rust skills directly applicable to protocol engineering.
Rust SDKs and tooling are central to interacting with Fuel-based systems.
protocols.about: Fuel is a modular execution-layer ecosystem where core protocol components (including Fuel Core) are built in Rust. For Rust engineers, it’s a direct path into protocol engineering: networking, storage, execution, and client tooling—plus Rust SDKs for integrations.
protocols.teaser: Modular execution layer and ecosystem with core components implemented in Rust (Fuel Core).

protocols.name: Starknet (Rust stack)
protocols.one_liner: Rust tooling and clients around Starknet, including Rust-based implementations like Pathfinder.
rust_relevance: Pathfinder is a Rust full node implementation for Starknet that showcases Rust protocol engineering in ZK ecosystems.
protocols.about: Starknet is a ZK-focused ecosystem where Rust shows up in real protocol engineering work—most notably in Rust full node implementations like Pathfinder. If you want to work on high-performance clients, indexing, and infra around ZK chains, the Starknet Rust stack is a strong entry point.
protocols.teaser: Rust tooling and clients around Starknet, including Rust-based implementations like Pathfinder.

protocols.name: Internet Computer (ICP)
protocols.one_liner: On-chain canisters (services/smart contracts) with first-class Rust support via the Rust CDK.
rust_relevance: Rust is a primary language for writing Internet Computer canisters via cdk-rs.
Many canister workflows are Rust-native (candid interfaces, stable memory patterns).
protocols.about: The Internet Computer runs canisters—deterministic services deployed on-chain. Rust is a first-class option for canister development, making ICP relevant for Rust teams building decentralized backends and on-chain services.
protocols.teaser: Rust canisters let you ship on-chain services with real backend semantics—state, upgrades, and stable memory patterns.

tools.name: Anchor
tools.description: Dominant framework for writing Solana programs with higher-level macros and workflows.
tools.about: Anchor is the dominant framework for building Solana programs in Rust: it standardizes account validation, IDL generation, testing workflows, and deployment ergonomics.

youtube.title: Solana Developer Bootcamp (Anchor workflows appear throughout)

tools.name: Solana Program Library (SPL)
tools.description: Reference on-chain programs and interfaces used across the Solana ecosystem.

links.migration_note: The original solana-labs/solana-program-library repo is archived; active programs have moved under the solana-program GitHub org.

tools.about: SPL is the reference set of Solana on-chain program standards (tokens, associated token accounts, etc.). Even if repos shift over time, SPL concepts define interoperability.

tools.name: near-sdk-rs
tools.description: Core Rust SDK for writing NEAR smart contracts.
tools.about: near-sdk-rs is the core Rust toolkit for building NEAR smart contracts, including macros, serialization patterns, and developer utilities.

tools.name: near-workspaces-rs
tools.description: Rust library for automating workflows and writing tests for NEAR smart contracts.
tools.about: near-workspaces-rs is the go-to Rust library for testing and scripting NEAR contract workflows: deploy, call, view, and assert behavior end-to-end.

tools.name: Polkadot SDK
tools.description: Monorepo providing core components to build on Polkadot/Substrate.
tools.about: The Polkadot SDK is the Rust-first toolkit for building Substrate-based chains and runtimes (WASM), powering major parts of the Polkadot ecosystem.

tools.name: ink!
tools.description: Rust-based smart contract toolkit that compiles to WASM for ink!-compatible chains.
tools.about: ink! is a Rust smart contract framework that compiles to WASM for ink!-compatible chains. It provides macros, storage modeling, and testing utilities for production-grade contracts.

youtube.title: ink! 101 (Parity) — smart contracts in Rust → WASM

tools.name: subxt
tools.description: Rust/WASM library for interacting with Substrate-based chains.
tools.about: subxt is the modern Rust client library for Substrate chains, enabling strongly-typed RPC, metadata-driven codegen, and WASM-friendly clients.

tools.name: parity-scale-codec
tools.description: Rust implementation of the SCALE codec used heavily in Substrate runtimes.
tools.about: SCALE (Simple Concatenated Aggregate Little-Endian) is Substrate’s canonical encoding. parity-scale-codec is the Rust implementation used throughout runtimes and tooling.

tools.name: CosmWasm
tools.description: Rust smart contracts for Cosmos ecosystems compiled to WASM.
tools.about: CosmWasm is the Rust-to-WASM smart contract stack across many Cosmos appchains. It’s a production-proven architecture with strong shared patterns and libraries.

tools.name: cw-plus
tools.description: Shared CosmWasm contracts and libraries used across production projects.
tools.about: cw-plus is the shared CosmWasm contract and library suite: reusable patterns and components used in real deployments.

tools.name: rust-optimizer
tools.description: Optimized contract build pipeline commonly used for CosmWasm releases.
tools.about: rust-optimizer provides reproducible, optimized builds for CosmWasm contracts—often a default in production release pipelines.

tools.name: Substreams
tools.description: High-performance blockchain indexing where developers write Rust modules to transform chain data streams.
tools.about: Substreams lets you write Rust modules that transform blockchain data streams into structured outputs for indexing. It’s built for speed and reproducible data pipelines.

tools.name: Reth
tools.description: Modular Rust implementation of an Ethereum execution layer client.
tools.about: Reth is a modular Rust Ethereum execution client focusing on performance, correctness, and clean architecture for node operators and researchers.

tools.name: Alloy
tools.description: Modern Rust libraries for interacting with EVM chains (successor direction to ethers-rs).
tools.about: Alloy is a modern Rust stack for building EVM integrations: types, transports, signing, and tooling—positioned as the forward direction for Rust EVM development.

tools.name: rust-bitcoin
tools.description: Core Rust library for Bitcoin data structures and network messages.
tools.about: rust-bitcoin is the foundational Rust library for Bitcoin protocol data structures and message parsing—used by wallets, indexers, and infrastructure projects.

youtube.title: Learn Rust by building a simple Bitcoin wallet (community tutorial)

tools.name: Bitcoin Dev Kit (BDK)
tools.description: Suite of Rust libraries for building modern descriptor-based wallets.
tools.about: BDK (Bitcoin Dev Kit) accelerates wallet development with descriptor-based wallets, key management patterns, and a composable Rust library set.

tools.name: Lightning Dev Kit (LDK)
tools.description: Lightning implementation packaged as a Rust SDK.
tools.about: LDK (Lightning Dev Kit) is a Lightning implementation packaged as a Rust SDK so applications can integrate Lightning payments without running a full node stack.

tools.name: borsh-rs
tools.description: Deterministic binary serialization format widely used in Rust smart contract ecosystems.
tools.about: Borsh is a deterministic binary serialization format popular in Rust smart contract ecosystems (notably Solana and NEAR) where predictable layouts matter.

tools.name: RustSec Advisory Database
tools.description: Community security advisories for Rust crates published on crates.io.
tools.about: RustSec Advisory DB is the primary community database of Rust crate security advisories, powering tools like cargo-audit.

tools.name: Soroban SDK (Rust)
tools.description: Rust SDK for writing Soroban smart contracts compiled to WASM.
tools.about: Soroban’s Rust SDK provides the macros, types, and host bindings to author contracts in Rust and compile to WASM for Stellar’s Soroban environment.

tools.name: Soroban CLI
tools.description: CLI tooling for building, deploying, and interacting with Soroban contracts.
tools.about: The Soroban CLI is used in the standard developer workflow: compile contracts, manage identities, deploy, and interact with contract methods from the terminal or CI.

tools.name: Stylus SDK (Rust)
tools.description: Rust SDK for building Arbitrum Stylus contracts compiled to WASM.
tools.about: Stylus SDK provides Rust bindings and ergonomic patterns for writing WASM smart contracts that execute in the Stylus environment on Arbitrum.

tools.name: cargo-stylus
tools.description: Cargo subcommand for building and deploying Stylus Rust contracts.
tools.about: cargo-stylus streamlines the Rust-to-WASM workflow for Stylus: building, optimizing, and packaging contracts for deployment.

youtube.title: Stylus Pro Series (Rust smart contracts on Arbitrum)

tools.name: OpenZeppelin Rust Contracts for Stylus
tools.description: Rust contract library patterns for Stylus, inspired by OpenZeppelin’s security-first approach.
tools.about: OpenZeppelin’s Rust-for-Stylus work is part of bringing well-known security patterns and audited approaches into Rust-native smart contract development on Arbitrum Stylus.

article.title: OpenZeppelin Rust Contracts for Stylus (official docs)

tools.name: Lighthouse
tools.description: Leading Rust Ethereum consensus (beacon chain) client.
tools.about: Lighthouse is a production Ethereum consensus client implemented in Rust, widely referenced in the broader Rust-in-crypto narrative for performance and correctness.

tools.name: cargo-audit
tools.description: Audits Cargo.lock against the RustSec Advisory Database.
tools.about: cargo-audit is the standard Rust dependency security scanner, checking your dependency graph against RustSec advisories.

article.title: Inside Rust: Keeping secure with cargo-audit 0.18

tools.name: cargo-deny
tools.description: Dependency policy enforcement for Rust: licenses, bans, advisories, sources.
tools.about: cargo-deny enforces supply-chain policies (licenses, duplicated crates, advisories) and is common in security-sensitive Rust codebases including crypto infra.

tools.name: cargo-nextest
tools.description: Next-generation Rust test runner optimized for CI and large workspaces.
tools.about: cargo-nextest speeds up test execution with parallelization and better output—useful in large Rust monorepos (common in protocol and node development).

tools.name: curve25519-dalek
tools.description: Rust implementation of Curve25519 and Ristretto group operations.
tools.about: A widely used Rust cryptography library for Curve25519 primitives. It’s foundational in many signature and ZK-related stacks.

tools.name: ed25519-dalek
tools.description: Rust Ed25519 signatures implementation built atop dalek primitives.
tools.about: A common Rust Ed25519 implementation used in protocols and applications that need deterministic signatures and audited primitives.

tools.name: arkworks
tools.description: Rust ecosystem for zkSNARKs and cryptographic primitives.
tools.about: arkworks provides a modular set of Rust crates for zkSNARKs and crypto primitives, widely used in research and production tooling.

tools.name: Plonky2
tools.description: High-performance zkSNARK proving system implemented in Rust.
tools.about: Plonky2 is a Rust ZK proving system known for speed and recursion support, often referenced in performance-focused ZK engineering.

tools.name: Aptos Core
tools.description: Core Aptos blockchain implementation (Rust-heavy).
tools.about: The main Aptos codebase implemented largely in Rust—useful reference for Rust-first blockchain node engineering practices.

tools.name: Sui (core repo)
tools.description: Core Sui blockchain implementation (Rust-heavy).
tools.about: The main Sui codebase in Rust—valuable for teams studying high-performance Rust networking and runtime patterns.

tools.name: Sui Rust SDK
tools.description: Rust SDKs and client libraries for interacting with Sui.
tools.about: Rust client libraries for Sui enable building indexers, infra services, and application backends around the Sui network.

tools.name: Rust Toolchain (rustc + Cargo)
tools.description: The Rust compiler and package manager—foundation of everything in the ecosystem.
tools.about: The Rust toolchain includes the `rustc` compiler, Cargo (build + dependency manager), standard library, and official tooling. On rust.dev, treat it as the canonical starting point for serious systems development and production Rust.

tools.name: rust-analyzer
tools.description: Language server powering code intelligence for Rust in VS Code and other editors.
tools.about: rust-analyzer provides modern Rust IDE features (completion, goto definition, inline type hints) via the Language Server Protocol. It's the default engine behind the Rust Analyzer extension in VS Code.

tools.name: Clippy
tools.description: Official linter with hundreds of lint rules for idiomatic, correct Rust.
tools.about: Clippy helps teams keep Rust code idiomatic and correct by surfacing lints in CI and editor tooling. It's distributed with Rust via rustup components.

tools.name: rustfmt
tools.description: Official Rust formatter.
tools.about: rustfmt enforces consistent formatting across Rust codebases. Standardizing formatting removes bikeshedding and makes diffs smaller and reviews faster.

tools.name: Miri
tools.description: Interpreter for Rust MIR that helps catch undefined behavior in unsafe code.
tools.about: Miri runs Rust code in an interpreter to detect undefined behavior (UB) such as out-of-bounds accesses and invalid aliasing—especially valuable for `unsafe` heavy crates.

tools.name: crates.io
tools.description: Official Rust package registry.
tools.about: crates.io is the official package registry for Rust libraries and applications. It is central to discovery and supply-chain security practices in Rust.

tools.name: docs.rs
tools.description: Hosted Rust API documentation for crates.
tools.about: docs.rs automatically builds and hosts API docs for crates published to crates.io, enabling consistent documentation discovery and linking across the ecosystem.

tools.name: lib.rs
tools.description: Alternative crates index and discovery interface for Rust libraries.
tools.about: lib.rs provides a fast index and browsing experience for Rust crates, organized by categories and popularity signals.

tools.name: Rust Playground
tools.description: Run and share Rust snippets in the browser.
tools.about: The Rust Playground is the fastest way to try small Rust code examples and share them in issues, documentation, and community discussions.

tools.name: Tokio
tools.description: Dominant async runtime and ecosystem for production Rust services.
tools.about: Tokio is the most widely used async runtime for Rust servers and networking-heavy apps. It provides an async scheduler, I/O, utilities, and an ecosystem of compatible crates (hyper, tonic, tower, axum).

tools.name: Axum
tools.description: Ergonomic web framework built on Tower.
tools.about: Axum builds on Tower's middleware ecosystem to create composable HTTP services. It is a common choice for modern Rust APIs, especially in the Tokio ecosystem.

tools.name: actix-web
tools.description: High-performance web framework for Rust.
tools.about: actix-web is a mature, high-performance Rust web framework widely used in production. It's known for speed, composability, and a strong ecosystem of integrations.

tools.name: hyper
tools.description: Low-level HTTP library powering much of Rust's web ecosystem.
tools.about: hyper provides fast, correct HTTP implementations used by higher-level frameworks and clients. It forms part of the foundational networking stack for many Rust services.

tools.name: tonic
tools.description: gRPC implementation for Rust built on Tokio + Tower.
tools.about: tonic is the go-to gRPC framework in Rust, offering strong async performance, streaming, and interoperability with common protobuf toolchains.

tools.name: serde
tools.description: The de-facto serialization framework in Rust.
tools.about: serde enables high-performance serialization and deserialization across formats (JSON, CBOR, MessagePack, etc.). It's one of Rust's most foundational ecosystem crates.

tools.name: reqwest
tools.description: Ergonomic HTTP client for Rust.
tools.about: reqwest is the go-to HTTP client crate for building Rust services and CLIs that talk to web APIs. Built on hyper, with TLS integrations and async support.

tools.name: clap
tools.description: Command-line argument parser with derive macros.
tools.about: clap is the standard library for building high-quality CLIs in Rust, supporting derive-based argument definitions, help generation, completions, and rich validation.

tools.name: tracing
tools.description: Structured, async-aware instrumentation for Rust.
tools.about: tracing provides structured, scoped, async-friendly instrumentation. It's widely used for production observability in Rust services, often paired with OpenTelemetry exporters.

tools.name: sqlx
tools.description: Async, compile-time checked SQL for Rust.
tools.about: sqlx enables async database access with compile-time SQL checking (via offline mode), helping teams keep queries safe and maintainable without a heavy ORM.

tools.name: Diesel
tools.description: A safe, extensible ORM and query builder for Rust.
tools.about: Diesel provides strongly-typed query building and compile-time checks for many patterns. It is a long-running choice for teams who want a Rust-native ORM approach.

tools.name: SeaORM
tools.description: Async & dynamic ORM for Rust.
tools.about: SeaORM is an async ORM designed for productivity, featuring entity codegen and a flexible query API—often paired with Axum or Actix in modern web stacks.

tools.name: Criterion.rs
tools.description: Statistics-driven benchmarking harness for Rust.
tools.about: Criterion.rs provides robust, statistically sound benchmarking to track performance changes over time—critical for systems teams and high-load services.

tools.name: proptest
tools.description: Property-based testing framework for Rust.
tools.about: proptest generates structured random test cases and shrinks failing inputs, helping teams catch edge cases and invariants violations early.

tools.name: wasm-bindgen
tools.description: High-level interactions between Rust and JavaScript for WebAssembly.
tools.about: wasm-bindgen facilitates ergonomic bindings between Rust and JS when compiling to WebAssembly, powering a large part of the Rust-to-web ecosystem.

tools.name: wasm-pack
tools.description: Build and package Rust-generated WebAssembly for the web.
tools.about: wasm-pack streamlines compiling Rust to WebAssembly and publishing packages, integrating with npm and common JS workflows.

tools.name: Wasmtime
tools.description: A fast, secure WebAssembly runtime.
tools.about: Wasmtime is a leading WebAssembly runtime under the Bytecode Alliance umbrella. It's used in server-side and embedded scenarios where sandboxing and portability matter.

tools.name: Spin (WebAssembly microservices)
tools.description: Developer toolchain for building WASM microservices (often in Rust).
tools.about: Spin is a WebAssembly application framework enabling fast-starting components for edge and serverless-like deployments. Rust is a first-class language for Spin apps.

tools.name: embedded-hal
tools.description: Hardware Abstraction Layer traits for embedded Rust.
tools.about: embedded-hal defines common traits for embedded drivers and HAL implementations, enabling portable embedded Rust code across MCU families.

tools.name: Embassy
tools.description: Async embedded framework for Rust (no_std).
tools.about: Embassy brings async/await to microcontrollers, providing a powerful executor, HAL integrations, and networking support for embedded Rust teams.

tools.name: RTIC
tools.description: Real-Time Interrupt-driven Concurrency framework for embedded Rust.
tools.about: RTIC provides a structured concurrency model for real-time embedded systems, making interrupts and resource sharing explicit and analyzable.

tools.name: probe-rs
tools.description: Embedded debugging, flashing, and probing tools in Rust.
tools.about: probe-rs provides a modern toolchain for flashing and debugging embedded targets, with CLI and library components used by embedded Rust workflows.

tools.name: defmt
tools.description: Efficient logging framework for embedded Rust.
tools.about: defmt enables compact, structured logging for embedded environments, helping teams debug without blowing flash/RAM budgets.

tools.name: Bevy
tools.description: Data-driven game engine built in Rust.
tools.about: Bevy is a modern Rust game engine with ECS at its core. It’s popular for rapid iteration, tooling ergonomics, and a fast-growing plugin ecosystem.

tools.name: wgpu
tools.description: Safe, portable GPU abstraction for Rust (WebGPU native).
tools.about: wgpu is a Rust graphics API inspired by WebGPU, enabling modern GPU rendering across platforms. It underpins many Rust graphics and game projects.

tools.name: Rapier
tools.description: 2D/3D physics engine for Rust.
tools.about: Rapier is a high-performance physics engine for games and simulations, commonly used with Bevy and other Rust game stacks.

tools.name: macroquad
tools.description: Simple and fast game library for Rust (2D-focused).
tools.about: macroquad is a lightweight Rust game framework designed for quick iteration and portability, popular for small games, prototypes, and jams.

tools.name: Candle
tools.description: Rust-native ML framework by Hugging Face.
tools.about: Candle is a minimalist ML framework written in Rust, developed by Hugging Face. It targets fast inference and modern ML workflows with a Rust-first API.

tools.name: Burn
tools.description: Rust deep learning framework with a focus on performance and flexibility.
tools.about: Burn is a Rust deep learning framework designed for end-to-end workflows. It aims to balance ergonomics with performance and supports modern training/inference patterns.

tools.name: Polars
tools.description: Fast DataFrame library implemented in Rust (with bindings).
tools.about: Polars is a high-performance DataFrame library implemented in Rust, known for speed and an expression API. It's used for analytics workloads and has bindings in multiple languages.

tools.name: Apache DataFusion
tools.description: Rust-native query engine built on Apache Arrow.
tools.about: Apache DataFusion is a fast, extensible query engine written in Rust, enabling SQL and DataFrame queries over Arrow memory structures and Parquet data.

tools.name: TiKV
tools.description: Distributed transactional key-value store written in Rust.
tools.about: TiKV is a production-grade distributed key-value store built in Rust. It's widely cited as a flagship Rust systems project for high-load infrastructure and storage.

tools.name: Vector
tools.description: High-performance observability data pipeline written in Rust.
tools.about: Vector is a fast telemetry pipeline for logs and metrics, implemented in Rust for performance and safety at scale.

tools.name: linkerd2-proxy
tools.description: Rust data-plane proxy for the Linkerd service mesh.
tools.about: linkerd2-proxy is the Rust-based data plane powering Linkerd, showcasing Rust at scale in low-latency networking infrastructure.

tools.name: ripgrep
tools.description: Fast line-oriented search tool (rg).
tools.about: ripgrep is a famously fast Rust CLI tool for searching text, often used as a flagship example of Rust performance and CLI ergonomics.

tools.name: bat
tools.description: A cat clone with syntax highlighting and Git integration.
tools.about: bat is a popular Rust CLI app that improves on `cat` with syntax highlighting, paging, and Git context.

tools.name: fd
tools.description: A simple, fast alternative to `find`.
tools.about: fd is a Rust CLI tool designed as a user-friendly alternative to `find`, with sensible defaults and strong performance.

tools.name: Starship
tools.description: Cross-shell prompt written in Rust.
tools.about: Starship is a fast, customizable cross-shell prompt. It's one of the most visible Rust-built developer tools due to broad daily usage.

tools.name: Helix Editor
tools.description: Modal text editor built in Rust with LSP support.
tools.about: Helix is a modern modal editor in Rust, integrating language servers out of the box and focusing on sane defaults and performance.

tools.name: Fuel Core
tools.description: Rust implementation of the Fuel full node (Fuel Core).
tools.about: Fuel Core is the Rust-based node implementation for the Fuel ecosystem, relevant for protocol engineering, performance work, and client development.

tools.name: fuels-rs
tools.description: Rust SDK for interacting with Fuel.
tools.about: fuels-rs provides Rust tooling for building apps and integrations on Fuel, including transaction building and network interactions.

tools.name: Pathfinder
tools.description: Rust full node implementation for Starknet.
tools.about: Pathfinder is a Rust-based implementation for Starknet infrastructure, useful for developers focusing on ZK ecosystems and Rust protocol engineering.

tools.name: Tower
tools.description: Composable networking middleware and Service abstractions powering much of Rust’s async web stack.
tools.about: Tower provides the Service trait and a rich middleware ecosystem used by hyper, tonic, and axum. If you’re building high-performance Rust services, understanding Tower unlocks most of the modern stack.

tools.name: prost
tools.description: Fast Protocol Buffers implementation for Rust, commonly used with tonic for gRPC services.
tools.about: prost is the go-to Protobuf compiler/runtime in Rust production services. Pair it with tonic to ship gRPC APIs with strong typing and great performance.

tools.name: warp
tools.description: A fast, composable web framework built on hyper with an ergonomic filter-based API.
tools.about: warp is a mature, high-performance choice for building HTTP APIs on top of hyper. It’s especially attractive if you like a functional/composable approach to routing and middleware.

tools.name: Rocket
tools.description: Batteries-included web framework focused on developer experience and type-safe request handling.
tools.about: Rocket emphasizes correctness and ergonomics with type-safe routes, request guards, and fairings. Great for product teams that want a cohesive framework experience.

tools.name: Tauri
tools.description: Build tiny, secure cross-platform desktop apps with a Rust backend and web UI.
tools.about: Tauri is the Rust-forward alternative for shipping desktop apps with a strong security model and small binaries. It’s a flagship example of Rust powering real end-user products.

tools.name: Leptos
tools.description: A fast Rust/WASM framework for building reactive web apps with fine-grained reactivity.
tools.about: Leptos is a leading Rust frontend framework with an impressive performance story. Pair it with server functions or an API backend to build full-stack apps in Rust.

tools.name: Yew
tools.description: A mature Rust/WASM framework for building client-side web apps with a component model.
tools.about: Yew is one of the longest-running Rust/WASM UI frameworks. If you want a stable component model and a large ecosystem of examples, Yew is a strong pick.

tools.name: Dioxus
tools.description: A Rust UI framework spanning web, desktop, and mobile—with a React-like developer experience.
tools.about: Dioxus aims to unify Rust UI development across platforms. It’s a great option if you want a single mental model for web + desktop apps with Rust.

tools.name: egui
tools.description: Simple, fast immediate-mode GUI for Rust—popular for tools, editors, and in-engine UIs.
tools.about: egui is the go-to immediate-mode GUI for Rust. It’s excellent for internal tools, debuggers, and applications where iteration speed matters.

tools.name: Iced
tools.description: Cross-platform GUI library inspired by Elm, focused on a clean architecture and predictable updates.
tools.about: Iced provides a structured, message-driven approach to GUI apps in Rust—great when you want a clean state/update model and cross-platform support.

tools.name: anyhow
tools.description: Ergonomic error handling for applications—easy context, backtraces, and error propagation.
tools.about: anyhow is the standard choice for application-layer error handling in Rust. Pair it with thiserror for library errors and you get a clean, scalable error strategy.

tools.name: thiserror
tools.description: Derive macro for creating rich, readable error types in Rust libraries.
tools.about: thiserror makes it trivial to build strongly-typed error enums. It’s widely used across the ecosystem and pairs perfectly with anyhow for applications.

tools.name: miette
tools.description: Beautiful, structured diagnostics for Rust CLIs—think compiler-style error reports.
tools.about: miette helps you ship compiler-grade error messages in your CLI tools. It’s ideal for developer tools, parsers, and anything where diagnostics are part of UX.

tools.name: Rayon
tools.description: Data-parallelism library that makes it easy to parallelize CPU-bound work safely.
tools.about: Rayon is the default answer for CPU parallelism in Rust. It provides parallel iterators that keep code clean while delivering huge speedups.

tools.name: parking_lot
tools.description: Fast, compact synchronization primitives (Mutex/RwLock/etc.) used in high-performance Rust codebases.
tools.about: parking_lot offers faster and more flexible locking primitives than std in many cases. It’s a common optimization choice in high-throughput systems.

tools.name: Crossbeam
tools.description: Concurrency tools for Rust: channels, scoped threads, and lock-free data structures.
tools.about: Crossbeam provides battle-tested concurrency building blocks used across the ecosystem. Great for building high-load services, schedulers, and data pipelines.

tools.name: DashMap
tools.description: A concurrent HashMap for Rust—simple API, strong performance under contention.
tools.about: DashMap is a practical concurrent map that feels like std::collections::HashMap. Useful whenever you need shared mutable maps without reinventing locking.

tools.name: cargo-chef
tools.description: Speed up Docker builds for Rust by caching dependencies intelligently.
tools.about: cargo-chef is one of the most impactful productivity tools for Rust in CI/CD. It splits dependency compilation from app compilation to maximize Docker layer caching.

tools.name: cargo-binstall
tools.description: Install Rust binaries from prebuilt artifacts when available—fast installs, less compiling.
tools.about: cargo-binstall dramatically speeds up onboarding by installing prebuilt binaries (when provided) instead of compiling everything from source.

tools.name: cargo-make
tools.description: Task runner for Rust projects—define workflows for build/test/lint/release.
tools.about: cargo-make helps teams standardize Rust workflows across repos: build pipelines, release tasks, and dev scripts—without bespoke shell glue.

tools.name: cargo-watch
tools.description: Watch files and run cargo commands automatically—tight feedback loops for Rust dev.
tools.about: cargo-watch is a lightweight quality-of-life tool: save a file, rerun tests, rebuild, or restart your app automatically.

tools.name: PyO3
tools.description: Build native Python modules in Rust and call Python from Rust safely.
tools.about: PyO3 is the default bridge between Rust and Python. It powers many high-performance Python extensions and is a key tool for AI/data teams adopting Rust.

tools.name: maturin
tools.description: Build and publish Python packages backed by Rust extensions (often with PyO3).
tools.about: maturin makes Rust → Python packaging straightforward. It’s the fastest path to shipping Rust performance inside Python ecosystems.

tools.name: napi-rs
tools.description: Build super-fast Node.js addons in Rust via Node-API (N-API).
tools.about: napi-rs is a production-ready way to bring Rust performance to JavaScript/TypeScript apps—great for crypto tooling, image processing, and servers.

tools.name: Trunk
tools.description: Build and bundle Rust/WASM web apps with a smooth dev server experience.
tools.about: Trunk is a top-tier developer tool for Rust/WASM frontends. It handles bundling, assets, and dev server workflows with minimal friction.

tools.name: Alacritty
tools.description: GPU-accelerated terminal emulator written in Rust.
tools.about: Alacritty is one of the most popular Rust desktop/infra apps: fast, minimal, and performance-obsessed. It’s a great example of Rust in end-user tooling.

tools.name: Zellij
tools.description: Terminal workspace and multiplexer built in Rust—powerful layouts, plugins, and sessions.
tools.about: Zellij brings modern UX to terminal multiplexing with Rust performance and safety. Ideal for developers who live in terminals.

tools.name: Deno
tools.description: Secure JavaScript/TypeScript runtime built in Rust, with a modern tooling story.
tools.about: Deno is a flagship Rust-powered developer platform. For Rust.dev, it’s a canonical example of Rust’s impact beyond libraries—shipping a full runtime ecosystem.

tools.name: SWC
tools.description: Fast Rust-based platform for compiling and bundling JavaScript/TypeScript.
tools.about: SWC is an industrial-scale Rust compiler project used across the JS ecosystem. It demonstrates Rust’s performance and safety advantages in real-world developer infrastructure.

tools.name: Firecracker
tools.description: AWS-built microVM technology for secure, high-density virtualization—implemented in Rust.
tools.about: Firecracker is one of the most high-impact Rust systems projects in production (microVMs). It’s a powerful reference point for Rust in security-critical, high-load infrastructure.

tools.name: Meilisearch
tools.description: Open-source, fast search engine built in Rust with a developer-friendly API.
tools.about: Meilisearch is a popular Rust-built search engine used in production for product search and discovery. It’s a great pick for teams wanting fast setup and a clean API.

tools.name: Sycamore
tools.description: Reactive Rust UI framework for the web (WASM), inspired by SolidJS-like ergonomics.
tools.about: Sycamore is a Rust-first reactive UI library targeting WebAssembly. It focuses on performance and ergonomics for building interactive web apps in Rust.

tools.name: Slint
tools.description: UI toolkit for native and embedded apps, with strong Rust bindings and a dedicated UI language.
tools.about: Slint targets both desktop and resource-constrained embedded devices. It ships a design toolchain and first-class Rust integration for building polished UIs.

tools.name: winit
tools.description: Cross-platform window creation and event loop library used across Rust GUI and graphics stacks.
tools.about: winit is the de-facto windowing/event-loop layer for many Rust graphics and GUI frameworks. It's foundational for app shells and game engines.

tools.name: wry
tools.description: Cross-platform WebView library powering desktop apps (Tauri stack).
tools.about: wry provides a safe, cross-platform WebView abstraction. Commonly used for building desktop apps with a web UI and Rust backend (e.g., Tauri).

tools.name: Fyrox
tools.description: 2D/3D game engine written in Rust with an editor and scene graph architecture.
tools.about: Fyrox is a Rust-native game engine with a built-in editor, asset pipeline, and runtime designed for practical game development.

tools.name: ggez
tools.description: Lightweight 2D game framework for Rust inspired by LÖVE.
tools.about: ggez is a pragmatic 2D game framework for quick prototypes and indie projects, with a simple API that feels familiar to LÖVE developers.

tools.name: godot-rust (GDExtension bindings)
tools.description: Rust bindings for Godot via GDExtension, enabling Rust gameplay code inside Godot projects.
tools.about: godot-rust lets you write Godot game logic in Rust while using Godot's editor, scenes, and tooling. Great for teams that want Rust performance + Godot iteration speed.

tools.name: rust-sdl2
tools.description: Rust bindings for SDL2 (graphics, input, audio) for games and multimedia apps.
tools.about: SDL2 remains a popular cross-platform layer for games and multimedia. rust-sdl2 provides Rust bindings used by many 2D engines and custom game projects.

tools.name: tch-rs
tools.description: Rust bindings for PyTorch (libtorch) to build and run ML models in Rust.
tools.about: tch-rs makes it possible to train or run inference with PyTorch models from Rust by binding to libtorch. Useful for embedding ML into Rust services or CLI tools.

tools.name: tract
tools.description: ONNX and TensorFlow inference in Rust (pure Rust engine), designed for production embedding.
tools.about: tract is a self-contained Rust ML inference engine. It's valuable for production use cases where embedding inference into Rust apps/services matters (and Python isn't desired).

tools.name: linfa
tools.description: Rust ML toolkit inspired by scikit-learn: clustering, regression, preprocessing, and more.
tools.about: linfa is a classic ML library in Rust with a scikit-learn-like approach. Useful for data science and on-device ML prototypes in Rust.

tools.name: rust-bert
tools.description: NLP pipelines and transformer model inference in Rust (Hugging Face models support).
tools.about: rust-bert provides ready-to-use NLP pipelines (summarization, translation, classification) and transformer model support in Rust.

tools.name: tokenizers
tools.description: Fast tokenization library (Hugging Face) implemented in Rust with Python/Node bindings.
tools.about: tokenizers is a high-performance Rust implementation of common tokenization algorithms used in modern NLP and LLM workflows. Widely used across the HF ecosystem.

tools.name: esp-hal
tools.description: no_std HAL for Espressif chips (ESP32 family) enabling embedded Rust development.
tools.about: esp-hal is the heart of the esp-rs embedded ecosystem: a no_std hardware abstraction layer that unlocks Rust on ESP microcontrollers.

tools.name: stm32-rs
tools.description: Rust device crates and tooling for STM32 microcontrollers (SVD → PAC generation).
tools.about: stm32-rs powers many STM32 PAC and HAL crates used in embedded Rust. If you're shipping Rust firmware on STM32 devices, this ecosystem is core infrastructure.

tools.name: Internet Computer Rust CDK (cdk-rs)
tools.description: Rust canister development kit for the Internet Computer.
tools.about: cdk-rs is the Rust toolkit for writing Internet Computer canisters (smart contracts/services). It provides APIs for stable memory, inter-canister calls, and candid interfaces.

tools.name: ic-agent
tools.description: Rust agent library for interacting with the Internet Computer (query/update calls, identities).
tools.about: agent-rs powers Rust integrations with the Internet Computer, enabling apps and services to authenticate and call canisters from Rust code.

creators.name: Jon Gjengset

news.title: Solana Breakpoint 2026 heads to London
news.deck: Dates announced for mid-November 2026; a key event for Rust-based Solana program developers.
news.about: Solana confirmed that Breakpoint 2026 will take place in London (Olympia) in mid-November. This matters for Rust builders because Solana programs are commonly authored in Rust and Anchor dominates the workflow.

news.title: NEARCON 2026 announced for San Francisco
news.deck: NEAR’s flagship event returns in Feb 2026—relevant for near-sdk-rs developers and ecosystem partners.
news.about: NEARCON’s 2026 edition is scheduled for late February in San Francisco (Fort Mason). For Rust developers, it’s the highest-signal place to track near-sdk-rs patterns, testing workflows, and ecosystem direction.

news.title: RustConf 2026 announced for Montréal
news.deck: A cornerstone Rust event—important for builders across crypto infrastructure and protocol engineering.
news.about: RustConf 2026 in Montréal is a key date for teams shipping Rust in production—protocol engineering, infra, and security-heavy shops included.

news.title: Alloy: the modern Rust stack for EVM interactions
news.deck: If you’re building Rust services that talk to EVM chains, Alloy is positioned as the forward-looking toolkit.
news.about: Alloy is a modern Rust library stack for interacting with EVM chains. If you run Rust services that talk to Ethereum or L2s, Alloy is a forward-looking foundation for RPC, types, and signing workflows.

news.title: Stylus Rust SDK hits a major milestone (0.8.0)
news.deck: Offchain Labs’ Stylus SDK makes Rust→WASM smart contracts on Arbitrum dramatically more approachable.
news.about: The Stylus SDK release on crates.io marks a tangible step toward Rust-native smart contracts in EVM ecosystems—while keeping dev workflows closer to Cargo than Solidity toolchains.

news.title: RustConf 2025 talks playlist is live
news.deck: Catch up on the best production Rust talks, now in one official playlist.
news.about: When you want the “state of production Rust,” conference talks are one of the best signals. The RustConf 2025 playlist is a strong feed for compiler, tooling, and real-world patterns that spill over into protocol engineering.

news.title: Stellar Meridian 2026 dates announced
news.deck: Stellar’s flagship conference returns in Oct 2026—high relevance for Soroban (Rust smart contracts) builders.
news.about: If you’re building Rust smart contracts with Soroban, Meridian is where ecosystem direction and key talks usually land first.

youtube.title: Meridian 2025: It’s never been better to build on Stellar

news.title: RustJobs.dev is a useful hiring signal (and a shortcut for candidates)
news.deck: A dedicated Rust job board is a clean source for both recruiters and devs—especially when you want real Rust roles, not keyword spam.
news.about: Job listings are noisy across general boards. A Rust-focused board can help filter to roles that actually ship Rust (including crypto infra teams hiring for protocol engineering).

news.title: Rust 1.92.0 released
news.deck: Latest stable Rust release (Dec 11, 2025). Great time to re-index new features and update learning materials.
news.about: Rust 1.92.0 is a stable toolchain release. Use this as a canonical news anchor for version-specific documentation updates, migrations, and 'what's new' content.

news.title: TokioConf 2026 announced
news.deck: TokioConf lands in Portland on April 20, 2026—high-signal for async Rust and service engineering.
news.about: TokioConf focuses on async Rust and the Tokio ecosystem: performance, correctness, observability, and production patterns for services.
news.date_notes: Curated highlight posted on rust.dev; see sources for canonical event dates.

news.title: Rust Week 2026 dates published
news.deck: Rust Week returns to Utrecht, May 18–23, 2026—one of the best community weeks to meet maintainers.
news.about: Rust Week is a longstanding community week. Expect a mix of talks, workshops, and deep technical conversations across Rust domains.
news.date_notes: Curated highlight posted on rust.dev; see sources for canonical event dates.

news.title: Rustikon 2026 heads to Warsaw
news.deck: Rustikon will take place March 19–20, 2026 in Warsaw, Poland.
news.about: Rustikon is a growing Rust conference series. Great for discovering talks and connecting with the European Rust community.
news.date_notes: Curated highlight posted on rust.dev; see sources for canonical event dates.

news.title: FOSDEM 2026 schedule is live — Rust Devroom is listed
news.deck: If you want the highest-signal snapshot of what the Rust ecosystem is building, the Rust Devroom at FOSDEM is a must-watch. Use this as your canonical hub link.
news.about: FOSDEM is a flagship open-source conference, and the Rust Devroom is consistently a dense stream of maintainer-level talks. We track it here so Rust.dev can act as a stable entry point for schedules, streams, and post-event recordings.

news.title: embedded world 2026 dates confirmed
news.deck: Embedded Rust keeps gaining ground. If you ship firmware or safety-critical systems, embedded world is one of the best places to track the intersection of Rust + hardware.
news.about: embedded world is a major embedded systems conference. Rust engineers can use it to discover vendor support, tooling trends, and talk recordings that reflect real-world constraints.

news.title: Rust 1.93 release window and tooling notes
news.deck: Rust releases every six weeks. This entry links the official schedule + a notable musl target update announcement for teams shipping static Linux binaries.
news.about: Use this as a stable anchor for release timing and toolchain-impacting announcements. If your org ships musl-linked binaries, track the musl target updates closely before rolling upgrades across fleets.

learning_paths.title: Rust Foundations (for serious builders)
learning_paths.summary: Ownership, error handling, traits, async fundamentals—enough to read real codebases.
learning_paths.audience: Developers moving into Rust for infrastructure/protocol work.
learning_paths.about: This track is designed for builders who want to read and contribute to real Rust codebases (clients, runtimes, infra services)—not just finish toy projects.

learning_paths.title: Solana Programs with Anchor (Rust)
learning_paths.summary: Learn Solana program basics with Rust, then ship with Anchor workflows.
learning_paths.about: A fast path to shipping Solana programs in Rust, with Anchor workflows and a security-first checklist.

learning_paths.title: Substrate Smart Contracts with ink! (Rust → WASM)
learning_paths.summary: Write Rust smart contracts that compile to WASM for ink!-compatible chains.
learning_paths.about: Build ink! contracts that compile to WASM and follow Substrate ecosystem standards.

learning_paths.title: NEAR Smart Contracts in Rust
learning_paths.summary: Ship contracts with near-sdk-rs and adopt testing workflows with workspaces.
learning_paths.about: Ship NEAR contracts with near-sdk-rs and adopt realistic testing via near-workspaces-rs.

learning_paths.title: CosmWasm Contracts (Rust → WASM)
learning_paths.summary: Build CosmWasm contracts and ship optimized builds for production deployments.
learning_paths.about: Write CosmWasm contracts with reusable patterns (cw-plus) and ship optimized release builds.

learning_paths.title: Soroban Smart Contracts (Rust → WASM)
learning_paths.summary: Write Rust smart contracts for Stellar’s Soroban and learn the end-to-end deploy + interact workflow.
learning_paths.audience: Rust developers who want a Rust-first smart contract environment outside Solana/Cosmos/Substrate.
learning_paths.about: Soroban is one of the cleanest Rust-to-WASM smart contract stacks available. This track keeps you on a production-focused path (testing, deploy, security).

learning_paths.title: Arbitrum Stylus Contracts (Rust → WASM on EVM)
learning_paths.summary: Learn Stylus fundamentals and build Rust contracts that execute on Arbitrum via WASM.
learning_paths.audience: Rust engineers who want EVM reach without writing Solidity.
milestones: State, storage patterns, and ABI surfaces
learning_paths.about: Stylus is the “Rust enters the EVM” moment. This track focuses on a real workflow: Cargo-first, tests, and safer patterns.

learning_paths.title: Rust Security & Supply Chain (for production teams)
learning_paths.summary: Practical security hygiene: advisories, dependency policy, CI enforcement, and release discipline.
learning_paths.audience: Teams shipping Rust in production (protocols, infra, wallets) who need repeatable security workflows.
milestones: Threat model for Rust dependency supply chain
learning_paths.about: Security is a workflow. This path collects the minimal set of tools and habits that make Rust codebases safer at scale.

learning_paths.title: Rust Web Services (Tokio + Axum)
learning_paths.summary: Build production APIs: async fundamentals, HTTP, middleware, observability, and database access.
learning_paths.audience: Backend engineers building high-load services in Rust.
learning_paths.about: A pragmatic track for teams shipping Rust APIs. Focuses on patterns that scale: timeouts, cancellation, backpressure, observability, and error handling.

learning_paths.title: Embedded Rust (Bare metal → Async with Embassy)
learning_paths.summary: Go from no_std basics to real firmware workflows with flashing, debugging, and async concurrency.
learning_paths.audience: Engineers building firmware on microcontrollers using Rust.
learning_paths.about: Embedded Rust is a deep ecosystem. This track prioritizes workflows (flash/debug/log) and concurrency models that help you ship firmware confidently.

learning_paths.title: Rust Gamedev with Bevy
learning_paths.summary: Learn ECS concepts, rendering, assets, and game architecture while shipping small projects quickly.
learning_paths.audience: Rust developers curious about games, simulations, and interactive apps.
learning_paths.about: Bevy is one of the fastest-growing Rust ecosystems. Shipping a small game is a great way to learn performance and architecture in a fun loop.

learning_paths.title: ML in Rust (Candle + Burn)
learning_paths.summary: Run inference and build ML-powered services with Rust-first ML frameworks.
learning_paths.audience: Engineers who want Rust ergonomics and safety for ML inference and pipelines.
learning_paths.about: Rust ML is evolving quickly. This track focuses on practical inference and service integration using Rust-native frameworks.

learning_paths.title: Rust Data Engineering (Polars + DataFusion)
learning_paths.summary: Fast analytics pipelines and query engines in Rust, from DataFrames to SQL engines.
learning_paths.audience: Data engineers and infra teams building fast analytics backends.
learning_paths.about: Rust is increasingly used for analytics engines and pipelines. This track is the fastest route to building a Rust-based data backend.

jobs.title: Embedded Rust Jobs (RustJobs.dev search)
jobs.about: Embedded Rust-oriented job feed via RustJobs.dev. Good starting point for firmware, device software, and embedded systems roles.

jobs.title: Remote Rust Jobs (Remote OK feed)
jobs.about: A quick way to browse remote-first Rust roles across startups and global teams. Treat as a lead generator—verify details on the employer site.

jobs.title: Rust GameDev Jobs (search hub)
jobs.about: Jump-off page for Rust game development roles. This entry aggregates links to studios and engines that commonly hire Rust developers (engine, tools, networking, graphics).
